resources.string: Observe one of the yamas (non-violence, truthfulness, non-stealing, continence or Brahmacharya, nonmaterialism), directing your actions and speech, while observing your thoughts.
Allow your actions to come from conscious choice rather than as a result of habit.
Observe one of the niyamas (purity, contentment, training senses, self-study, surrender)
Observe all of your actions and ask yourself, “why am I doing this action?”
Observe one of the five elements (earth, water, fire, air, space), externally and internally.
Observe one of the five cognitive senses (hearing, touching, seeing, tasting, smelling).
Be aware of your breath today, noticing its qualities and how it relates to thoughts and emotions.
Observe one of the five active senses (speaking, grasping, moving, reproducing, eliminating).
Notice how fears can control you, and how fears are related to imagination.
Observe one of the four functions of mind (manas, chitta, ahamkara, buddhi).
Speak very little today—only what is accurate, purposeful, and non-hurting.
Observe your reactions when a desire, expectation, want, or need is or is not fulfilled.
Observe your gestures and body language, noticing how they reflect thoughts and emotions.
Observe one of the yamas (non-violence,truthfulness,non-stealing, continence or Brahmacharya, nonmaterialism), directing your actions and speech, while observing your thoughts.
Practice one-pointedness, paying attention to whatever you are doing today.
Observe one of the niyamas (purity,contentment, training senses, self-study, surrender)
Resolve that today “I will love every one and not hate anyone today.”
Observe one of the five elements (earth, water, fire, air, space), externally and internally.
Observe whether your “first thoughts” or “second thoughts” are good or bad, clear or clouded.
Observe one of the five cognitive senses (hearing, touching, seeing, tasting, smelling).
Be aware of the principle of meditation in action.
Observe one of the five active senses (speaking, grasping, moving, reproducing, eliminating).
Be aware of how you adjust to changing circumstances around you.
Observe one of the four functions of mind (manas, chitta, ahamkara, buddhi).
Observe how you relate to other people.
Observe your reactions when a desire, expectation, want, or need is or is not fulfilled.
Notice which thoughts coming into your mind are “useful” or “not useful.”
Choose one of the primitive fountains (food, sleep, sex, self-preservation) and observe how it affects your other desires, emotions, thoughts, speech, and actions.
Witness everything, external and internal (in months which have 31 days).
Dialogue with yourself about mistakes you have made. Don’t condemn yourself or be judgmental.
When sitting for meditation, ask your mind to go to, and to heal aching parts. When you attempt sushumna application, ask your mind to focus on the nose bridge.
Ask yourself, “what do I want?” Raise questions about the purpose of life.
Explain to your mind that it is too worldly and materialistic.
Train the senses by using dialogue; actually dialogue with the individual ten senses.
Ask yourself if you want to meditate, to explore, to know yourself, and to choose your habits.
Ask how you think, why you are emotional, and what the problems are with your mind.
Establish a relationship, a friendship with your mind; learn to love by being gentle with yourself.
Ask yourself, “what do I want?” This may relate to small things or to the purpose of life.
Tell the mind that it has become dissipated, and should tread the path of light, love, and devotion.
Self-counsel about negative emotions. When upset, ask, “why am I thinking like this?”
Ask your mind to open a blocked nostril for you. Ask your mind to flow with the breath.
Consider some problem and ask your mind “what are some solutions? what should I do?”.
Dialogue with that whatever is being observed, including mental objects and thoughts.
Ask yourself, “what do I want?” Remind yourself of your real identity.
Ask yourself why you are doing certain actions. How do the actions reflect thoughts and emotions?
Say to your mind, “please be my friend.” How does your mind respond?
Ask your mind what you have to do. Ask why you sometimes do not do what you want to do.
When distracting thoughts come, remind yourself of your purpose; tell yourself that this thought or desire is distracting and will lead you to a fantasy.
Ask “does my ego get in my way or not?” Spend a few minutes simply being honest with yourself.
Ask yourself, “what do I want?” This may relate to small things or to the purpose of life.
Ask why you become emotionally disorganized, forget things, and do not attend to things properly.
When sitting for meditation, say to your mind, “mind, please go beyond the senses.”
While doing breathing practices ask your mind to “please flow with the breath.”
Make a contract with the mind to let the mind whisper those inner secrets to you, and put all things in front of your mind. Discuss this “contract” with your mind.
Ask the mind why it disturbs you in meditation. How can meditation be improved?
Ask yourself, “what do I want?” You will learn many things when you dialogue.
Consider some choices you face in life and ask buddhi, “should I do it or not?”
Ask “is my first thought good or bad—is it clear or clouded?” Your second or third thoughts?
Ask your mind what your fears are and what to do with them.
Say to your mind “please be my friend.” (in months with have 31 days )

I have already clicked the link

Our approach to teaching and training at Abhyasa Ashram is one of coaching in one-to-one or small group sessions (satsang). The purpose of coaching sessions on the Self-Assessment outline is to help you learn how to self-assess. The Self-Assessment is truly intended to be an assessment by yourself of yourself. The coach is not here to analyze you or diagnose you like a typical medical or psychological assessment might be done. It is your personal exploration of your own current state of life and being. The coach has done this before and is here to facilitate your own introspection and observation.The items of self-awareness listed below are from the perspective of yoga as seen through the tradition. By increasing self-awareness one gradually comes to see that these are not who we really are, which leads to the realization of the witness of these, the true Self.
What to look for in each area of self-assessment?
For each of the areas of self-assessment, have the following orientations of what to look for:
• What am I doing well that I need to continue doing?
• What am I doing that I need to do more of?
• What am I doing that I need to reduce or stop doing entirely?
• What am I not doing that I need to start doing?
• In what way does this relate to my current situation?
• How might I plan with this in relation to my future situation?
• Quarterly complete Self-Assessment and needs analysis

Wherever there are points that draw your attention, for which you have some need to do something, change something, etc., then check that item and make your note in the space below. Press next or swipe left to start the self-awareness assessment.

Initially, this may seem complex with lots of jargon to memorize. Rather quickly, however, it becomes natural to witness these aspects of your being. Gradually, you come to realize the one who is observing these various aspects of our self-structure (antahkarana, or inner-instrument). This leads to the doorway of deep meditation and contemplation.
To start a new assessment press the button on the bottom right
Do you want to exit without saving this assessment?
Do you want to delete this assessment?
